text: Predictability and Balance
label: HH2

text: Remarks of Commissioner Nils J. Diaz
label: BODY

text: United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission
label: BODY

text: Before the Special Symposium
label: BODY

text: America’s Energy Challenge - The Nuclear Answer
label: BODY

text: Texas A&M University
label: BODY

text: College Station, TX
label: BODY

text: November 19, 2001
label: BODY

text: It is a real pleasure to speak today at this special symposium on  America’s Energy Challenge -
label: BODY

text: The Nuclear Answer.  I will be presenting my individual views today.  They do not necessarily represent
label: BODY

text: the views of the U.S.  Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC), except when indicated.
label: BODY

text: I was asked to express my views on what is necessary to move forward with the new national energy
label: BODY

text: policy and the prominent role of nuclear energy.  I will focus on what I believe the NRC needs to do.
label: BODY

text: But I do not want my position on what now are critical issues to be lost in the discussion.  I
label: BODY

text: believe it is my responsibility to deal first with national security considerations, i.e., security at nuclear
label: BODY

text: facilities.  Therefore, I would like to state that:
label: BODY

text: I strongly believe that having abundant and reliable energy is a national security issue.
label: BODY

text: Moreover, it is a given that nuclear energy is an essential component of the energy portfolio of
label: BODY

text: the United States.
label: BODY

text: I will work to ensure that common defense and security activities are an integral component of
label: BODY

text: the NRC’s regulatory framework.  These activities should be conducted as an enhancement, not
label: BODY

text: a detriment, to our protection of public health and safety.
label: BODY

text: I will continue striving to maintain nuclear power and radiation technologies as safe and as
label: BODY

text: useful to the people of America as they are and should be.
label: BODY

text: We all live with the realization that the attacks of September 11 have changed our lives and the
label: BODY

text: way we do business.  What I am not willing to accept is that anyone but the United States of America
label: BODY

text: determines how we are going to change.  Freedom and the pursuit of happiness are at the core of our
label: BODY

text: democracy, and no one is going to take them away from us.  We must defend our way of life, not only
label: BODY

text: from terrorism, but from those misguided interests that, even when well intended, could be harmful to
label: BODY

text: our national interests and energy security is high on the list of vital national interests.
label: BODY

text: There are multiple assaults being launched - and in crescendo voices - using the attacks of
label: BODY

text: September 11 to unjustifiably brand nuclear facilities as highly vulnerable and as dangerous as an
label: BODY

text: “American Chernobyl”.  I answer these voices by saying that America’s nuclear facilities are hardened
label: BODY

text: in multiple ways and have the best physical security of any industrial infrastructure in the country.  As
label: BODY

text: you know, nuclear power plants in the U.S. have effective inherent capabilities to protect health and
label: BODY

text: safety through such features as robust containment buildings, redundant safety systems, highly trained
label: BODY

text: operating crews, and tested emergency plans.  The bottom line is that the public health and safety would
label: BODY

text: ultimately be protected, even if the containment is somehow damaged by an airplane.  The containment
label: BODY

text: is not the last line of defense, it is but one line of defense.  America will protect its people, acting
label: BODY

text: beyond site boundaries if needed.
label: BODY

text: Nuclear power plants compare quite favorably with many large and complex industrial facilities,
label: BODY

text: including chemical plants, in terms of operational safety, safety infrastructure and physical protection.
label: BODY

text: It is important to state to the American public that nuclear power plants are specifically designed and
label: BODY

text: operated to protect against a terrorist attack and acts of sabotage.
label: BODY

text: I do not believe the doomsday scenarios being portrayed for nuclear facilities because, among
label: BODY

text: other things, they do not take into account the decisive and powerful resources that the country would
label: BODY

text: use to interdict and mitigate the consequences of a terrorist attack on any of our facilities that have
label: BODY

text: hazardous materials.  In addition, licensees and the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission maintain very
label: BODY

text: effective and frequently tested emergency plans whose sole purpose is to reduce hazards to the public.  I
label: BODY

text: can assure you that our licensees, the NRC, and Federal, State, and local officials, work together to
label: BODY

text: achieve a high degree of safety and security.
label: BODY

text: It is true that the operation of industrial complexes involves risks, which are not zero, but which
label: BODY

text: were not expected to be zero.  A small radioactive release, or even a large radioactive release under
label: BODY

text: some very extreme circumstances, cannot be completely ruled out.   What I am going to rule out is that
label: BODY

text: the health consequences of a Chernobyl-like scenario would be applicable to the United States.
label: BODY

text: Chernobyl was much more than a catastrophic reactor failure and the release of enormous quantities of
label: BODY

text: radioactivity to the environment.  Chernobyl’s failure was the failure of a totalitarian society to protect
label: BODY

text: and care for its people after a disaster...and this horrific mishandling of public health and safety cannot
label: BODY

text: and is not going to happen in America.  We will take care of our people, promptly and passionately, as
label: BODY

text: September 11 has shown, taking risks to avoid risks.  Make no mistake, America will deliver the
label: BODY

text: necessary responses to protect public health and safety, and therefore, there will be no “American
label: BODY

text: Chernobyl.”
label: BODY

text: The Chernobyl disaster was costly in many ways, but the consequences were and are still being
label: BODY

text: exaggerated and distorted into something worse than what they were in terms of health effects.  For the
label: BODY

text: record, what really happened at Chernobyl, in terms of public health and safety, was:
label: BODY

text: a catastrophic release of radioactivity fueled by a fire in a combustible graphite reactor core,
label: BODY

text: without a containment, that burned for many hours
label: BODY

text: thirty-one prompt fatalities, twenty-eight due to acute radiation exposure of workers and firemen
label: BODY

text: that were sent to put out the fire (we now have a deeper appreciation of firemen everywhere)
label: BODY

text: no other prompt fatalities, outside or inside the site
label: BODY

text: one major, established delayed health effect, that is especially bad because it was avoidable:
label: BODY

text: about eighteen hundred children with thyroid cancer, with fewer than a dozen reported fatalities,
label: BODY

text: due to the callous disregard of the former Soviet Union for its people.  There are no other latent
label: BODY

text: cancers attributed to Chernobyl.  The 2000 UNSCEAR report states that “apart from this
label: BODY

text: [thyroid cancer] increase, there is no evidence of a major public health impact attributable to
label: BODY

text: radiation exposure 14 years after the accident.  There is no scientific evidence of increases in
label: BODY

text: overall cancer incidence or mortality or in non-malignant disorders that could be related to
label: BODY

text: radiation exposure.”
label: BODY

text: site recovery accomplished, with the other reactors continuing to operate for years;   permanent
label: BODY

text: shutdown will be effected years from now
label: BODY

text: substantial areas of land that were left radioactively contaminated and unused because of
label: BODY

text: financial constraints and political maneuvering.
label: BODY

text: I’d like to make additional points regarding the latent health effects of Chernobyl because the
label: BODY

text: word cancer, like the word radiation, can be used to strike fear in the minds of people.  Although
label: BODY

text: thyroid cancer is usually treatable, it can have serious consequences and can be life-threatening if
label: BODY

text: untreated.  Evacuation and the use of potassium iodide pills would have significantly reduced the
label: BODY

text: incidence of thyroid cancer.  Leukemia has been expected to be among the early primary latent health
label: BODY

text: effects seen among those exposed to significant amounts of radiation, yet excess cases of leukemia that
label: BODY

text: can be attributed to Chernobyl have not been detected.
label: BODY

text: I am not trying to compare in any way American reactors to Chernobyl-type reactors because
label: BODY

text: there is no comparison.  Our reactors are so much better and so is our society.  What I am trying to
label: BODY

text: portray is that the failure of the former Soviet Union to do what was needed to mitigate the accident
label: BODY

text: significantly contributed to its consequences.  Can the United States of America do better than that?
label: BODY

text: You bet we can.  Therefore, as we face the challenges of today and tomorrow, I will be publicly
label: BODY

text: responding to the doomsayers, to counter the unjustifiable fear that they can cause in our people and the
label: BODY

text: damage they could inflict to our common defense and security, our economy, and our well-being.
label: BODY

text: Now back to the future of nuclear energy.
label: BODY

text: Since I have been with the Commission, I have been stressing that whether we make changes  or
label: BODY

text: we stay the course, it is indispensable that our performance be predictable and fair.  Besides being
label: BODY

text: excellent regulatory policy, the socio-political nature of the uses of radiation and nuclear energy demand
label: BODY

text: predictability and fairness.
label: BODY

text: I believe that the NRC has been performing with predictability and fairness over the past few
label: BODY

text: years.  Predictability is essential for energy planning and it could very well be that it is needed now
label: BODY

text: more than ever.  The reason we are here today is to discuss the implications for nuclear energy
label: BODY

text: presented by the National Energy Policy for the United States that the President and the Vice President
label: BODY

text: of the United States delivered a short time ago.  This was a short time ago by the calendar, but it seems
label: BODY

text: like very old news in light of the events that have taken place in our nation and in the world.
label: BODY

text: The National Energy Policy is designed to help bring together business, government, local
label: BODY

text: communities and citizens to promote dependable, affordable and environmentally sound energy for the
label: BODY

text: future.  In this report, the President supports the expansion of nuclear energy in the United States as a
label: BODY

text: major component of the national energy policy.  Notably, the report states that the NRC has made great
label: BODY

text: strides to provide greater regulatory certainty while maintaining high safety standards.  It is worthwhile
label: BODY

text: to try to understand what I believe is a basis that underlies the potential for bringing nuclear power
label: BODY

text: generation to center-stage in the debate on the energy policy for our country.  Shown in Table 1 is a
label: BODY

text: compilation of important aspects of the debate, summarizing what has changed in 20 plus years.  The
label: BODY

text: predictability of technical, regulatory and operational safety is improved and appears to favor
label: BODY

text: development.
label: BODY

text: In the nation’s interest, the NRC has been asked, with due consideration for safety and
label: BODY

text: environmental protection, to consider as priorities for nuclear energy generation:
label: BODY

text: -  evaluating and expediting applications for licensing new reactors;
label: BODY

text: -  facilitating power uprates of existing plants; and,
label: BODY

text: -  relicensing existing nuclear power plants.
label: BODY

text: I believe it is appropriate now that these issues also be considered in the interest of the common
label: BODY

text: defense and security.  Each and every recommendation of the President’s report  is to be assessed within
label: BODY

text: the legal requirements established by the NRC mandate to ensure adequate protection of public health
label: BODY

text: and safety and the environment.
label: BODY

text: I will now summarize how the NRC has addressed, and I believe should continue to address,
label: BODY

text: the three NRC priority issues discussed in the national energy policy.
label: BODY

text: On the potential review and licensing of new advanced technology reactors, the NRC has been
label: BODY

text: preparing additional capabilities to respond to the nation’s demands.  Much groundwork was  done
label: BODY

text: early, and a lot of it is useful to address today’s issues.  10 CFR Part 52, “Early Site Permits; Standard
label: BODY

text: Design Certifications; and Combined Licenses for Nuclear Power Plants,” was promulgated in 1989
label: BODY

text: (and amended in 1992) to improve the efficiency of the regulatory licensing process.  I am convinced
label: BODY

text: that the present pathway for potential licensing success of certified or certifiable new reactor
label: BODY

text: applications is Part 52.  First, it exists -- not a minor issue. Secondly, it contains the requirements for
label: BODY

text: assurance of safety and the processes for their implementation.  And lastly, it can be upgraded to meet
label: BODY

text: technological advances that require new licensing approaches, without compromising safety.  The
label: BODY

text: statement of considerations for Part 52  states: “The future of nuclear power depends not only on the
label: BODY

text: licensing process but also on economic trends and events, the safety and reliability of the plants,
label: BODY

text: political fortunes, and much else.  The Commission’s intent with this rulemaking is only to have a
label: BODY

text: sensible and stable procedural framework in place for the consideration of future designs, and to make it
label: BODY

text: possible to resolve safety and environmental issues before plants are built, rather than after.”  This
label: BODY

text: statement is as timely now as it was then.  Significant work has been in progress in the past year to
label: BODY

text: address needs in this area.  The NRC is preparing to process the industry-announced early site permit
label: BODY

text: applications that are expected next year.
label: BODY

text: Another priority, and not a minor one for the present energy scenario for the United States, is
label: BODY

text: power uprates.  You are well aware that U.S. nuclear power plants have been increasing their power
label: BODY

text: rating by a few percent, with relatively small changes in equipment and operations.  This will probably
label: BODY

text: continue, but of added significance now are the extended power uprates that licensees are beginning to
label: BODY

text: request.  For example, supported by General Electric Topical Reports, as many as thirty Boiling Water
label: BODY

text: Reactors may submit applications for increasing their power rating up to twenty percent.   The NRC
label: BODY

text: recently approved a fifteen percent power uprate for Duane Arnold.  This was the first extended power
label: BODY

text: uprate completed.  Seven extended uprates are being reviewed by the NRC and more are expected.  The
label: BODY

text: industry estimates that up to ten percent additional power generation -- or about 10,000 MW electrical
label: BODY

text: capacity -- could be achieved in the next few years, if economic expectations for the power uprates are
label: BODY

text: met.  Earlier this year the Commission approved my policy memorandum on power uprates and
label: BODY

text: instructed the staff to give high priority to power uprates and allocate appropriate resources to
label: BODY

text: streamline the NRC power uprate review process to ensure that it is conducted in the most effective and
label: BODY

text: efficient manner.  All of these and most of the other regulatory improvements conform to the
label: BODY

text: Commission's decision to streamline our processes to focus attention on real safety.
label: BODY

text: In 1997, I spoke about the importance of license renewal to the stability and economics of
label: BODY

text: electricity generation in the United States.  I stated that license renewal must become a reality for a
label: BODY

text: significant part of the U.S. nuclear fleet prior to any further developments, including new orders.  I am
label: BODY

text: sticking by my views and note that it is becoming a reality.  Nuclear power plants, whose licenses are
label: BODY

text: extended by formal regulatory approval, are essential to maintaining the large infrastructure needed for
label: BODY

text: the effective development of nuclear power and, I believe, for the energy security of the United States.
label: BODY

text: I would like to share with you my simple recipe for achieving predictability and fairness in
label: BODY

text: nuclear regulation and everything nuclear:
label: BODY

text: be disciplined
label: BODY

text: be meaningful
label: BODY

text: be scrutable
label: BODY

text: and good things will happen.  This applies to everyone.
label: BODY

text: I have been addressing predictability, now let me discuss the need for balance.  Predictability
label: BODY

text: and balance is the name of this talk.  To achieve balance, the processes must be disciplined, be
label: BODY

text: meaningful and be scrutable.  This is applicable across the board, including the protection of the
label: BODY

text: national electrical supply and its assets, and the protection of public health and safety.  In our arena,
label: BODY

text: both the NRC and licensees must balance the need for security at nuclear power plants with the other
label: BODY

text: safety needs at these facilities.  Balanced efforts in the area of physical security and safety by the
label: BODY

text: industry and the NRC have been successful and demonstrate our security capability.
label: BODY

text: Let me conclude by restating that there have been no credible threats to any nuclear facility in
label: BODY

text: this country but, even if there is a terrorist attack on a nuclear facility, I believe that America has, and
label: BODY

text: will deliver, the necessary responses to protect public health and safety.  September 11 is a reality, a
label: BODY

text: reality that we are now facing and will continue to face.  It is also a reality that nuclear power plants are
label: BODY

text: vital to the energy security of this country and the well-being of its people.
label: BODY
